title: 103_hr3845
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Prohibition of Cigarette Sales to Minors in Federal Buildings and Lands Act". The Congress recognizes the significant health hazards of cigarette smoking and smokeless tobacco use, leading to 434,000 deaths annually. Tobacco products contain harmful additives and nicotine, costing the US over $60 billion in lost productivity and healthcare expenses. Despite known health risks, tobacco remains minimally regulated and easily accessible to youth nationwide. The Congress acknowledges the health risks of tobacco use, with 90% of adult smokers starting in adolescence. Over 3,000 children start smoking daily, leading to a billion packs consumed yearly. Studies show tobacco as a gateway to more harmful drugs, emphasizing the need to discourage tobacco use among minors. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Federal agency" refers to Executive agencies and specified entities in title 5, United States Code. "Federal building" includes structures owned by the United States or Federal agencies. "Minor" is defined as an individual under 18 years old, and "tobacco product" includes cigarettes and cigars. The term "tobacco product" includes cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, pipe tobacco, smokeless tobacco, snuff, and chewing tobacco. The text chunk discusses the ban on tobacco products vending machines and free samples in federal buildings. The Administrator of General Services and Federal agency heads must prohibit the sale of tobacco products in vending machines and the distribution of free samples in or around Federal buildings. Exceptions can be made for areas that also prohibit minors. The sale of tobacco products in vending machines and the distribution of free samples in or around Federal buildings must be prohibited by the Administrator of General Services for Federal buildings under their jurisdiction, or by the head of a Federal agency for buildings under their jurisdiction. Exceptions may apply in areas that also prohibit minors. SEC. 5. COMPLIANCE REPORT.

Within 90 days of this Act's enactment, the Administrator of General Services and agency heads must submit a report to Congress confirming compliance with the Act and listing the locations of tobacco vending machines in Federal buildings under their administration.

SEC. 6. APPLICATION TO THE UNITED STATES CAPITOL AND GROUNDS. The Senate and House Committees, in consultation with the Architect of the Capitol, must create regulations within 45 days of the Act's enactment to ban tobacco sales in vending machines and free samples in the Capitol Buildings. Exceptions can be made in areas that also prohibit minors. The term "Capitol Buildings" is defined as in a specific Act. The United States Capitol Grounds are regulated under the Act approved on July 31, 1946 (40 U.S.C. 193m(1)). SEC. 7. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit the authority of the Administrator of General Services or agency heads to restrict tobacco use in or around Federal buildings, except as provided under section 4(a).
